4. Habitat and isolation: Anaerococcus tetradius is typically found in the human microbiome, particularly in the skin and vaginal flora. It has been isolated from various clinical specimens, such as wound infections and abscesses.

5. Biochemical properties: Anaerococcus tetradius is catalase-negative and oxidase-variable. It can ferment carbohydrates, producing lactic acid as the primary end-product.

6. Importance: Anaerococcus tetradius is considered an opportunistic pathogen and has been associated with various human infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. It is also a member of the normal human microbiome and may play a role in maintaining a healthy microbial balance.

Overall, Anaerococcus tetradius is an anaerobic, Gram-positive coccoid bacterium that is part of the human microbiome and can potentially cause opportunistic infections in certain clinical contexts.
